text:
Business Review of the Year 2016 - May to August By Leicester Mercury | Posted: December 29, 2016 0 COMMENTS SHARES July: Pall-Ex founder Hilary Devey VIEW GALLERY Business Review of the Year 2016 - May to August X 
Copy link to paste in your message / July: Pall-Ex founder Hilary Devey May: Leicester Tigers won the won race to redevelop the Granby Halls site June: Barratt sales stayed positive despite Brexit 
MAY 
Leciester City win the league. 
Fashion retailer Joules pressed the button on a stock market flotation which valued the company at £140 million and netted £40 million for its founder. The Market Harborough firm, launched by Tom Joule in 1989, is said it would float on the London Stock Exchange's AIM market by the end of June. 
All Leisure, the travel company behind Page & Moy and Travelsphere, said it planned to leave the Alternative Investment Market (AIM) following months of tough trading conditions and job losses. 
Top news for Topps Tiles when the UK's largest tile retailer said same-store sales rose 4.7 per cent for the 26 weeks to April 2. 
While this marked a slower growth rate than a year ago, Topps said sales for the seven weeks to May 21 were up 8.4 per cent, compared to a 6.3 per cent rise a year ago, marking a "strong" start to the second half of its financial year. 
Topps employs about 200 people at its Enderby head office. 
Leicester Tigers won the win race to redevelop the Granby Halls site, right next door to its Welford Road ground. 
The rugby club wants to build an £18 million hotel and matchday fans zone. 
A graphic of the planned Tigers hotel 
JUNE 
The UK voted to leave the European Union, with voters in county towns overwhelmingly backing Brexit. 
Loughborough-based Intelligent Energy announced a management shake-up with Dr Henri Winand stepping down as chief executive with immediate effect. 
In a statement to the London Stock Exchange the company said: "In anticipation of the successful refinancing of the company, and the completion of the restructuring of the business, Dr Henri Winand and the board agreed that it was an appropriate time to review the leadership of the company." 
Out: Dr Henri Winand 
A value footwear retailer said it was launching a new format in a bid to stem falling sales. 
Shoe Zone, which has its headquarters in Humberstone Road, Leicester, saw revenues fall after closing loss making and temporary shops. 
The company said it planned to open three large out-of-town stores in August in the hope of attracting new customers. 
The biggest employers in Leicestershire reacted to the momentous Brexit vote, saying they were preparing for tough months ahead after Britain voted to leave the EU. 
Hundreds of millions of pounds was wiped off the value of county companies following the Brexit vote and David Cameron's announcement he was planning to step aside. 
Shares in Coalville housebuilder Barratt Developments fell 23 per cent, Next Plc lost about £1.25 billion in its market value as shares dropped 12 per cent and shares in Topps Tiles, of Enderby, were down 10 per cent. Dunelm, of Syston, saw its shares fall 12 per cent and brick-maker Ibstock was down 21 per cent. 
Many share prices went on to recover.
